physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top.

div.p: Here is a check for $50 I promised you on the first of August and entirely forgot to send. I am sorry I cannot make it $100, but things are not so bright with me as to enable me to do that at the moment. And, by the way, I think you owe me $77 from my last page of poems, but it seems to me better for me to send you a check and for you to send me one than to just have you send me the balance. It is more business-like this way.

I am awfully pleased with the looks of my poems in the September number .<anchor xml:id= "n1" "Lead Soldiers" came out very well I think, in spite of the printer forgetting some of the stanza spacing. I thank you very much for the pleasant little notice about me in the end, with its remark about the forthcoming book,and cheering up polyphonic prose. As to your article in answer to Conrad Aikenit is a perfect wonder — one of the best things I ever read, and I am absolutely delighted with it. By-the-way, I don't think I ever told you how much I liked some of your poems in the August number, particularly "e;From the Porch."e;

I got your postal from the Fair<anchor xml:id = "n2", and it made me die of longing to be there, but I have been on the treadmill all the summer getting through this book, and not able to go anywhere. It has been perfectly awful summer, and I hope the reception of the book will justify me for very nearly breaking down under it.

I ordered six copies of "e;Poetry"e; to be sent me from
the Old Corner Book Store , and they report they have not receive their September numbers yet. I have a theory that they lie dreadfully, for mine came a week ago. I told them to send a special order through for me, because I thought it just as well to send it through a book shop and make the book shop sit up and take notice. But if they have never written you, I wish you would send me six copies direct, and I will send you check for them.
I quite agree with what you say about Stevens's "e;Peter Quince."e; I think that is a splendid poem. What do you know about the man, anything?
hope you had a splendid time out West. I suppose you are safely back now?
div.closer: With a great deal of love

div.note: The Panama-Pacific International Exposition took place in San Francisco, CA from February 20 to December 4, 1915

Harriet Monroe praises Wallace Steven's "e;Peter Quince at the Clavier"e; in the column "e;Our Contemporaries"e; Poetry, Vol. 6, No. 6 (September 1915) as "e;the most exciting thing in Others"e; (pp. 316)
